title: How to Dodge Foodborne Illness

content: I can remember having a foodborne illness once, and I wouldn’t wish that much gastrointestinal discomfort on my worst enemy. I’m not alone, of course. Food is responsible for an estimated 48 million cases of illness every year in the U.S. and it’s not just from big outbreaks you hear about in the news.  Foodborne illness, also called food poisoning, can occur in your own backyard especially during the summer months. Here’s how to stay safe.

Bacteria that are naturally present in the soil, air, water, in our bodies, and in animals’ bodies are most often to blame for foodborne illness.  For example, viruses in some raw oysters can make you very sick, but proper cooking destroys them.

Microbes thrive in warm and humid conditions, and they can multiply to the point of irritating or infecting your digestive system to make you miserable. Allowing food to sit for hours without proper refrigeration at backyard barbecues, lakeside picnics, and beach parties is one way to invite trouble to gatherings with family and friends. Proper food handling is just as crucial for dodging foodborne illness.

sections.heading: How to Avoid Foodborne Illness
content: When I was in college, my food microbiology professor told the class to always assume that food was contaminated. At first, I was shocked because the U.S. has such a safe food supply. I quickly came to understand that he was largely referring to how we handle foods at home.

Proper food handling goes a long way to avoiding foodborne illness, and it includes several steps. Children, pregnant women, older adults, and people with weakened immune systems are at greater risk for foodborne illness, so take extra care when feeding these groups.
Here are some simple actions that offer protection:

Wash your hands before you prepare food and before you eat to prevent transmission of germs to cooked and raw foods, like fresh fruits and vegetables. If you don’t have running water at the beach, lake, or camp site, bring along jugs of water, soap, and paper towels to properly clean your hands and food utensils. When possible, wash fresh fruits and veggies before you leave the house.

content: When traveling with food, especially raw meat, chicken, or seafood, keep it chilled in a cooler with plenty of ice or frozen gel packs. Microbes multiply very slowly if at all at 40 F or less (which should be the temperature of your home refrigerator).
Always marinate foods in the refrigerator, and never reuse marinade that’s been in contact with raw meat or seafood. Don’t reuse platters or utensils that have touched raw meat, poultry, or seafood.

Avoid eating raw and undercooked meat, poultry, fish, and shellfish. Use a food thermometer to ensure the proper temperature for doneness: 145 F for beef, pork, and fish; 160 F for hamburgers and other ground meat; 165 F for chicken or turkey.

Don’t let raw or cooked food sit outside in warm weather unrefrigerated for more than 2 hours; 1 hour or less if the air temperature is about 90 F. If you leave food out for longer than suggested, throw it away.  Better safe than sorry.

sections.heading: Was It Something You Ate?
content: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or fever are all signs of foodborne illness that may occur within minutes to hours after eating. It’s not always easy to figure out if you’re sick because of contaminated food since many symptoms are similar to the flu.  If you ate with a group and other people have the same symptoms, food is likely to blame.

You may feel like it’s never going to end, but most cases of foodborne illness run their course between 12 and 48 hours. If you don’t feel better after 2 days, call your doctor, particularly if you’re still vomiting, have diarrhea, your fever is about 101 F, you’re lightheaded, or you're confused. You may be severely dehydrated if you have dry mouth, extreme thirst, headache, and dizziness and may require medical attention.
